p: The effect of rhamnolipids on the cancer cell lines HL-60, BV-173, SKW-3, and JMSU-1 has been determined for the C10C10 monorhamnolipid R1, and the corresponding C10C10 dirhamnolipid R2 [ 173]. R1 was the more potent of the two and inhibited cellular division at lower concentrations (IC 50) than R2. The mechanism of inhibition appeared to be the induction of apoptosis. Rahimi et al. [ 174] confirmed the anti-cancer properties of R1 and R2 (on the MCF7 human breast cancer cells) and the lower IC 50 of R1 (25.87 µg/mL) compared to R2 (31.00 µg/mL). Others have also confirmed the anticancer potential of rhamnolipids [ 175].
